entry.title: Severe Thunderstorm Warning issued January 30 at 10:34PM CST until January 30 at 10:45PM CST by NWS Lake Charles LA
entry.summary:
At 1034 PM CST, a severe thunderstorm was located over Reddell, or near Mamou, moving northeast at 60 mph.
HAZARD...60 mph wind gusts.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Expect damage to roofs, siding, and trees.
Locations impacted include... Turkey Creek, Bayou Chicot, Whiteville, Mamou, Ville Platte, Reddell, Indian Lake, Pine Prairie, Chicot State Park, St. Landry, and Bunkie.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued January 30 at 6:34PM HST until January 30 at 9:30PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall.
* WHERE...The island of Maui in Maui County.
* WHEN...Until 930 PM HST.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding on roads, poor drainage areas, and in streams. Ponding of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 630 PM HST, radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain over the slopes of Haleakala. The highest rain rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were near Ulupalakua and upslope from Kaupo. Additional heavy rainfall will also move over West Maui from the southwest over the next several hours. - This advisory includes the entire island of Maui.

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 930 PM HST THIS EVENING FOR THE ISLAND OF MAUI IN MAUI COUNTY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued January 30 at 6:32PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
At 632 PM HST, Doppler radar was tracking strong thunderstorms along a line extending from 16 miles south of Hawaii Kai to 25 miles south of Manoa to 32 miles south of Honolulu. Movement was northeast at 45 mph.
HAZARD...Wind gusts of 50 to 55 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Hoolehua, Maunaloa, Kualapuu, Kepuhi, Kalaupapa National Park, and Molokai Airport.

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued January 30 at 10:20PM CST until January 31 at 1:00AM CST by NWS Louisville KY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of central Kentucky, including the following counties, Breckinridge, Bullitt, Grayson, Green, Hancock, Hardin, Larue, Meade, Nelson and Ohio.
* WHEN...Until 100 AM CST /200 AM EST/.
* IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying and poor drainage areas. Overflowing poor drainage areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1020 PM CST /1120 PM EST/, Doppler radar indicated heavy rain due to thunderstorms. Minor flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly in the advisory area. Between 1 and 1.6 inches of rain have fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1 inch are expected over the area. This additional rain will result in minor flooding. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Elizabethtown, Leitchfield, Hodgenville, Hardinsburg, Radcliff, Vine Grove, Cloverport, Clarkson, Upton and Fordsville. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Watch issued January 30 at 8:16PM PST until February 2 at 10:00PM PST by NWS Sacramento CA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...The potential for flooding caused by excessive rainfall.
* WHERE...A portion of northern California, including the following areas, Carquinez Strait and Delta, Sacramento Valley, Motherlode, Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County, Northeast Foothills, Northern San Joaquin Valley, and Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County.
* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff will result in sharp rises on rivers, creeks, and streams. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Periods of moderate to heavy rainfall are expected with totals from 2 to 4 inches over 48 hours. Heaviest rain expected from Friday afternoon through Saturday morning.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Shasta Lake Area / Northern Shasta County; Northern Sacramento Valley; Central Sacramento Valley; Southern Sacramento Valley; Carquinez Strait and Delta; Northern San Joaquin Valley; Mountains Southwestern Shasta County to Western Colusa County; Northeast Foothills/Sacramento Valley; Motherlode

entry.title: Flash Flood Warning issued January 30 at 6:15PM HST until January 30 at 8:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
At 615 PM HST, rainfall of 1 to 2 inches per hour were occurring over east Oahu from Waimanalo to Hawaii Kai. The band of higher rain rates has moved east of Oahu into the Kaiwi Channel. Although rainfall has eased, stream levels remain elevated, especially along the windward slopes of the Koolau Range.
HAZARD...Heavy rain producing life threatening flash flooding.
SOURCE...Radar.
IMPACT...Significant and life threatening flooding in drainages, streams, rivers, roads, properties, and other low lying areas. Multiple public road closures expected, as well as landslides in steep terrain.
This warning includes the entire island of Oahu.

cap:parameter.value: FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM HST THIS EVENING FOR THE ISLAND OF OAHU IN HONOLULU COUNTY

entry.summary:

* WHERE...All the main Hawaiian islands.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued January 30 at 8:50PM EST until February 1 at 1:00PM EST by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
Rainfall amounts between 0.50-1.25 inches falling on a melting snowpack could contribute to significant rises on area rivers. These rises will certainly disturb areal river ice and could create ice jam flooding. At this time multiple forecast points are forecast to hit action stage but none are currently forecast to hit minor flood stage.

* WHEN...From 1 AM EST Friday through Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Rapid rises on rivers from rain and snow melt exacerbated by ice jams may result in localized flood issues.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued January 30 at 2:44PM AKST until January 30 at 9:00PM AKST by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
...SYSTEM MOVING THROUGH THE PANHANDLE BRINGING SNOW...
Snow showers are expected to continue through Thursday afternoon and evening as a low moves southward along the Gulf of Alaska coast, with periods of moderate to heavy snow expected. Heaviest and most persistent snow showers have been observed in downtown Juneau and Douglas, and on Western Prince of Wales Island. Snow accumulations will vary by location given convective nature of snow showers, leading to significant accumulation differences.
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Additional snow accumulations of 4 to 7 inches.
* WHERE...City and Borough of Juneau, Petersburg Borough and Prince of Wales Island.
* WHEN...Until 9 PM AKST this evening.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Snow accumulations are going to be hit and miss with the showers. The heaviest accumulations are expected to be in the Downtown Juneau and Douglas areas, and Petersburg as well as on Western Prince of Wales Island. Some areas will see significant snow accumulations while other areas could see minor snow accumulations. Expect times of moderate to heavy snow.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Prince of Wales Island

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued January 30 at 3:31PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
The North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality in Raleigh NC has issued a Code Orange Air Quality Action Day for Fine Particulates for Mitchell, Yancey, Burke, and McDowell Counties, from midnight tonight to midnight EST Friday night.
An Air Quality Action Day means that Fine Particulates concentrations within the region may approach or exceed unhealthy standards. For additional information, please visit the North Carolina Division of Air Quality Web site at https://airquality.climate.ncsu.edu/.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued January 30 at 2:15PM CST by NWS Lincoln IL
entry.summary:
As rain diminishes to drizzle tonight, areas of fog are expected to develop. Visibility will be below a mile at times, especially along the I-72 corridor. Some of the fog may be dense at times. A general improvement is expected Friday morning, as a front lifts north across the area.
Be sure to slow down if you encounter dense fog. Use low beam headlights if driving, and leave plenty of distance between you and the vehicle ahead.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued January 30 at 2:20PM EST until February 1 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Blacksburg VA
entry.summary:
Heavy rain may fall on a deep primed snowpack leading to the melt increasing. Flows in rivers may increase quickly and reach critical levels.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of Virginia, including the following areas, Alleghany VA, Bath, Bland, Craig, Giles and Tazewell and southeast West Virginia, including the following area, Monroe.
* WHEN...From 1 AM EST Friday through Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Heavy rainfall on top of residual snowpack will lead to increased runoff concerns. 1 to over 3 inches of rain is expected across the watch area. Rain rates could be heavy at times. This combined with snowmelt will lead to flooding concerns. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Tazewell; Bland; Giles; Craig; Alleghany; Bath; Monroe

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued January 31 at 3:47AM ChST until February 2 at 4:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 7 to 10 feet and dangerous rip currents.
* WHERE...For the High Surf Advisory, north facing reefs. For the High Rip Current Risk, north and east facing reefs.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM ChST Sunday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion. Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf will remain large and maintain a high risk of rip currents along north and east facing reefs through at least Sunday. Then the north and trade swells will diminish allowing surf to decrease by early next week.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued January 24 at 10:25AM EST by NWS Northern Indiana
entry.summary:
ESFIWX
Favorable conditions for possible river ice jams are expected over the next week.
Bitterly cold temperatures have created some ice formation on area rivers and with slight warming later this weekend and into early next week may make for favorable conditions for ice jams on area rivers and tributaries. River ice spotters are asked to report any ice jams or ice jam flooding. Any ice jam that develops will have the potential to cause rises on area rivers with little to no warning and isolated areas of flooding are possible.
This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons along area rivers should continue to monitor the latest forecasts over the next week.
